newsitem.title: SOUTH AFRICA: S.AFRICA TO PROBE FRUIT MARKETING MONOPOLY.
newsitem.headline: S.AFRICA TO PROBE FRUIT MARKETING MONOPOLY.

text.p: South African farm minister Derek Hanekom said on Thursday he planned a full probe of agricultural marketing monopolies such as the one held by deciduous fruit marketer Unifruco.
This follows the passing of the Marketing of Agricultural Products Act by parliament, which paves the way for abolishing marketing monopolies in agricultural products.
Unifruco and Outspan hold monopoly agency agreements to market deciduous fruit and citrus products and Hanekom said the question was whether they would retain them.

"The issue is how fast and what replaces it. I do not think that it is in our country's interest, despite the many arguments presented, to limit our exports to a single agency," Hanekom told a media briefing.
The appointment of an investigator would ensure that whatever steps were taken were "informed decisions taking into account some of the problems of the European market".
"I am not suggesting that we should go wild and go for a completely fragmented marketing system," Hanekom said.
"There will be a process of issuing licences but it certainly cannot be confined to one monopoly. You have got to give space to other people.
"For example, there is a company that has set itself up with strong connections in the United States which is at least a 31 percent black company and they have not been granted licences.
"At the moment I would argue that we are losing opportunities while, of course, Unifruco would argue that we are capturing a premium by acting through a single agency.
"I would question the validity of that argument. We are not going to unbundle Unifruco through any legislative measure, we are simply going to open up competition."
Unifruco had provided a good service, he said. "If it continues to do so, most fruit producers will choose to use Unifruco but it will not be a statutory matter."
Hanekom also said he planned a major investigation into the availability and affordability of food to ordinary consumers next year.
